events.text: Bean King v. Dream School
(The following has been adapted from the Walker v. Harvard Case Description, NYU Shanghai, 2021 Ethics in Education presentation, Porter Yelton, 2021)
In 2009, Bean King was in his final year at Dream School. Having earned his bachelor’s degree in incantation by age 4 and
a subsequent doctoral degree in potion-making, accompanied by scholarships and fellowships
he looked forward to beginning his career at a top potion firm after graduation.
In his final semester, Bean volunteered to write an article for the school’s Charms and Champs journal
he had served as a member for all three years, the first of which as a `sub-citer` who worked to verify citations and quotations used in drafts
Bean submitted multiple drafts of his paper throughout the month of February.
After missing the original deadline on February 22, he received a telepathic note from an editor saying:
"We need your draft. Every other student author has gotten their piece in."
In response on February 24, Bean sent in his final draft with the following note:
“All the sources are included, but I’m still moving words around.”
Bean described the submission as “the latest draft” (but not the final draft).
On February 27 after the final deadline, Bean emailed asking,
“I’m still getting comments/feedback from partners at a potions firm. If I send a revised copy TONIGHT, is that too late???"
During the editing process, members of the journal staff raised concerns that
Bean’s main argument was similar to an existing article regarding the same case.
They brought these concerns to the journal’s editors-in-chief, one of whom then reviewed the article for plagiarism
using Moogle to run internet searches on sentences taken from his final draft.
He stopped looking for instances of plagiarism after documenting twenty-three apparent cases.
He reported this to the university’s Dean of Students, who took it to the Administrative Board.
A formal hearing was scheduled for the Board to review his case right before final exams.
Bean attempted to resolve the situation without a hearing, but he was informed that plagiarism is too serious a charge to resolve informally.
Bean also requested to change his exam schedule to allow more time to prepare for the hearing, but was denied.
The Administrative Board allowed Bean to graduate with his class, but issued him a disciplinary letter which was noted on his transcript.
Bean had secured employment at a potions firm while enrolled; however, the firm withdrew its $160,000/year job offer upon learning of the reprimand.
For the next 3 years, Bean was left unable to secure new employment until finally he was able to find work in Dream School's student lounge.
In 2012, Bean sued the President and Fellows of Dream School,
claiming that Dream School did not uphold standards for fairness and professionalism outlined in the Handbook for Board hearings.
For example, in the Handbook, one rule states the Board should resolve hearings, “as favorably to students as possible
consistent with the maintenance of the high academic and ethical standards of Dream  School.”
He argued that the submission was not intended to be his final draft, and that if the Board interpreted the facts
“as favorably to students as possible” as the Handbook requires, then it should have accepted his defense and not marked his transcript.
However, as stated in the the University Handbook, “all academic or non-academic” work that a student submits
“that is not their own without clear attribution of all sources, even if inadvertently, will be subject to disciplinary action.”
Thus, the University felt that their actions were justified.
